s.text: With absolutely no malice aforethought (honest, it's just happened this way), Moneybox this week has been devoted to the thoroughly scintillating issues of double-parking and corporate accounting.
Along with GE, it's one of the few truly successful industrial conglomerates left in this country, with lines of business ranging from disposable medical products to underwater telecommunications.
Along with GE, it's one of the few truly successful industrial conglomerates left in this country, with lines of business ranging from disposable medical products to underwater telecommunications.
Along with GE, it's one of the few truly successful industrial conglomerates left in this country, with lines of business ranging from disposable medical products to underwater telecommunications.
If the cost of acquisition is hidden by a write-off, it's hidden in plain sight, since the company announces it quite publicly.
In particular, Tice pointed to Tyco's hefty write-offs of its acquisition costs, write-offs that have totaled something like $3.

Motorola, meanwhile, announced that it would be taking a $700 million write-off because of its investment in troubled satellite-phone company Iridium, and added that it might have to take an additional $350 million write-off in the next quarter.
